Rockets follow a smooth curve called a 'gravity turn'. They start off going nearly vertically upwards, and naturally tilt over as gravity saps the vertical speed but not the horizontal.  This is done for efficiency and to keep the angle of attack low when in atmosphere  12/

I framed getting to orbit as a two-stage process: 1) get to space, then 2) get to orbital velocity.  But notice that by the time our rocket was above the Kármán line, it had already picked up 2.3 km/s of horizontal velocity  11/

An example of this from machine learning is interpolating between normally distributed latent vectors for a generative model. Linear interpolation would vary the latent vector magnitude, so often spherical interpolation is used, e.g., https://t.co/e1zZ9JFDb0  13/

One consequence of this is that if you take an empirical mean of samples from a high dimensional Gaussian, you'll get a point that's in a sense not representative; the samples all have roughly the same magnitude, and the mean has much smaller magnitude  12/
In high dimensions, the distribution is still unimodal and the mean is still the point of highest density, but as you move outwards there's much, much more space than we're used to  11/

All of this is counterintuitive because we only ever visualise 1D and 2D Gaussians, so our intuitions come from there. We're used to thinking of the mean as being a representative point, and having most of the probability mass bunched up near it. 10/

This is the most surprising feature of the puzzle for me: for arbitrarily many prisoners, the probability of success is always > 1 - ln(2) ≈ 0.307.  When the puzzle was proposed by Peter Bro Miltersen, he assumed that the asymptotic probability of success would be zero!  21/
What if we let the number of prisoners N tend to infinity? In that case, the probability of failure is as follows   20/ https://t.co/Aq3Th6ibIo
The 100 prisoners succeed with probability 1 - (H_100 - H_50) ≈ 0.311. Remember, if they chose randomly the probability of success was 0.0000000000000000000000000000008!  19/

Therefore there are N!/k such permutations, so the probability that a random permutation has maximum cycle length k is 1/k, and the probability that the maximum cycle length is greater than N/2 is the following, where H_n is the nth harmonic number  18/ https://t.co/MHF48gPKaQ

How many permutations are there with a cycle of length k>N/2? There are N choose k ways to choose the elements of the cycle, (k-1)! ways to arrange the cycle elements without decomposing it into smaller cycles, and (N-k)! ways to arrange the elements not in the cycle  17/
Suppose we have a permutation on N elements that has a cycle of length k > N/2. Then it has to be the *only* cycle of length > N/2, and therefore also k is the maximum cycle length  16/
Fortunately, if we only care about the probability of maximum cycle lengths that exceed half the number of elements, there's a simpler approach (see https://t.co/aTno7x8ITi)  15/

Generally, calculating the probability of a given maximum cycle length of a permutation is pretty involved, and discussion about the 100 prisoners problem tends to approach it the hard way (see the wikipedia article for the puzzle, for example: https://t.co/epC1ATSC80)  14/
So the relevant question is: what's the probability that a permutation on 100 elements has a maximum cycle length of 50?  13/

It's essentially Bayesian inference with discrete blobs of probability mass. (In the simulation, I've done the re-sampling step after every measurement, because it makes it clearer what's going on) 6/

Initially, the 'particles' are equally weighted. When you make a measurement, you reweight each particle according to the likelihood of the measurement. When the weights become sufficiently unbalanced, you resample with replacement according to weight 5/

In a PF, your uncertainty of the system is represented by a discrete collection of possible states ('particles'). Each particle evolves according to the dynamics of the system (+ sampling whatever noise is involved) 4/

In a KF your current uncertainty of the system is represented by a Gaussian, the dynamics are linear + Gaussian noise, and measurements have Gaussian noise. All those assumptions together mean that at any time your uncertainty is captured by a MV Gaussian 3/

A particle filter (PF) does the same job as a Kalman filter (KF). Generally: you have a system in an unknown state, evolving over time according to some known dynamics + noise, and you occasionally get noisy sensor data. The task is to infer the current state 2/
